project.name: Rety
project.description:
Rety is a library that allows you to record the edits you make on one or more pieces of text (usually code) and replay them later to recreate the same typing flow.

This is particularly useful for orchestrating live demos that run without your presence.
project.innovation: The same progressive development, which is the primary benefit of live coding, but without the fumbling, delays, or mistakes that often come with it.

project.name: Color.js
project.description: Color conversion and manipulation library, developed jointly with [Chris Lilley](https://svgees.us).
project.innovation: Possibly the first entirely color space agnostic JS library, pioneered several API innovations.
project.impact: Used to generate figures and examples for several CSS specifications and influenced the [Color API](https://github.com/wicg/color-api)

project.name: md-block
project.description: A lightweight HTML custom element for Markdown that uses the popular [marked](https://marked.js.org/) library.

project.name: Parsel
project.description: A tiny, permissive CSS selector parser and specificity calculator.
project.impact:
- Developed to aid Web Almanac’s analysis, and used to this day.
- Used by Google’s Puppeteer project

project.name: MaVoice
project.description: A free app to vote on repo issues for any repo, that uses GitHub Issues as a backend. Made with Mavo.

project.name: LCH Color Picker
project.description: A color picker to explore LCH colors that are now being added to CSS. Made with Mavo.

project.name: Issue closing stats
project.description: An app to display issue closing stats for any repo. Made with Mavo.

project.name: Mavo
project.description:
Mavo is a programming language for non-programmers, empowering them to create full stack data-driven web applications by simply writing HTML.

This was the flagship project of my PhD, in the [Haystack Group at MIT CSAIL](https://haystack.csail.mit.edu/). I also supervised 3 Master’s students and 10 undergraduates and led them to meaningful contributions.
project.impact: Mavo’s innovations led to the publication of [several peer-reviewed research papers](https://lea.verou.me/publications/#research) and 3 Masters theses.
project.innovation:
* Hassle-free remote storage, simply by providing a URL, the rest is taken care for you.
* A formula language with several features that make it easier for novices.
* Removes the need to think about data modeling: novices generate their data schemas by simply designing their UI and annotating it
* Editing interface that is largely automatically generated to follow the UI

project.name: Bliss
project.description: Want to use Vanilla JS but find native APIs a bit unwieldy? Bliss is for you.

project.name: Stretchy
project.description: Form element autosizing, the way it should be.

project.name: Conic gradient polyfill
project.description: A polyfill for CSS conical gradients.
project.impact: [Encouraged browsers to implement CSS conic gradients](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=502970). Because the polyfill also implemented the double color stop position syntax, [browsers implemented that alongside](https://chromestatus.com/feature/5712111258828800), just so the examples in the polyfill page work correctly.

project.name: Multirange
project.description: A tiny polyfill for HTML5 multi-handle sliders.
project.impact: Was apparently used so much that its custom properties appeared in [Web Almanac's analysis of the top 1000 custom property names](https://almanac.httparchive.org/en/2020/css#naming)

project.name: Awesomplete
project.description: Ultra lightweight, customizable, simple autocomplete widget with zero dependencies.
project.impact: Featured on Github’s weekly Github Explore newsletter when it launched.

project.name: DPI love
project.description: More than you probably wanted to know about screen DPI.

project.name: corner-shape preview
project.description: Preview the corner-shape property before it’s implemented in browsers, through SVG.

project.name: Contrast Ratio
project.description: An app for testing whether a combination of CSS colors passes accessibility standards. Exited to [Siege Media](https://www.siegemedia.com/) in 2023.
project.impact: Became one of the most popular contrast checkers on the Web for years, and [was featured in several books](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22contrast-ratio.com%22+OR+%22leaverou.github.io%2Fcontrast-ratio%22&tbm=bks) and conference talks.
project.innovation: Unlike other tools at the time that only accepted hex codes it supported any CSS color the browser supported, even semi-transparent colors (by displaying a range of contrasts), which required original research.

project.name: Prism
project.description: A lightweight, extensible syntax highlighter, built with modern web standards in mind.
project.impact: Used in a number of high profile websites like [Mozilla Developer Network](https://developer.mozilla.org/), Google’s [web.dev](https://web.dev/), [Sitepoint](https://www.sitepoint.com/), [Smashing Magazine](http://smashingmagazine.com), [A List Apart](http://alistapart.com), [CSS Tricks](http://css-tricks.com) and many others. Over [8M downloads weekly on npm](https://www.npmjs.com/package/prismjs) and over [1bn cumulative downloads since its launch](https://npm-stat.com/charts.html?package=prismjs&from=2012-01-01).
project.innovation:
* Low floor: Entirely frictionless to get started, simply drop it in your page
* Very high ceiling: Pioneered an extensibility mechanism allowing plugins to completely change how it works
* Pioneered a declarative, hierarchical syntax for defining language grammars that made it easy for anyone who understood regular expressions to add support for a new language, which helped getting it to 300 languages very quickly.

project.name: The CSS3 Test
project.description: High coverage testsuite for the most stable CSS modules. 50,000 unique visitors on its launch.
project.impact: Motivated browser vendors such as [Mozilla](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=913153) or [WebKit](https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=79073) to support more CSS3 features to increase their scores on it.

project.name: Dabblet
project.description: An interactive CSS playground.
project.impact: Was quite successful for a few years, with thousands of visitors every day. Several popular industry media like [Wired.com’s WebMonkey](http://www.webmonkey.com/2011/12/dabblet-an-interactive-css-playground-in-your-browser/), [CSS-Tricks](http://css-tricks.com/dabblet/), [Smashing Magazine](http://www.smashingmagazine.com/smashing-newsletter-issue-50/) and others wrote about Dabblet’s release. During its first month, it received more than 65Κ unique visitors, 15Κ of which during its first two days.
project.innovation:
* Pioneered a distributed serverless architecture using almost entirely client-side code, with Github Gists as a storage backend.
* Its inline previewers for various value types predate similar features in today's editors.

project.name: Animatable
project.description: A CSS transitions gallery that shows what's possible with even the most basic of transitions: one property, two values.

project.name: -prefix-free
project.description: -prefix-free was a library that allowed authors to write standard, prefix-less CSS and have the necessary prefixes added on runtime. Was gradually abandoned as browsers moved away from vendor prefixes, so the problem it was solving practically disappeared.
project.innovation: Used feature detection for almost everything instead of hardcoded lists, allowing it to remain extremely lightweight and always up-to-date regardless of its version.

project.name: cubic-bezier.com
project.description: A tool that helps you work with the easing functions of CSS3 transitions & animations and share them with others.
project.impact: Featured on several [books](https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22cubic-bezier.com%22) and talks. Its code was at some point even [included in the Firefox browser](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2014/07/event-listeners-popup-media-sidebar-cubic-bezier-editor-more-firefox-developer-tools-episode-33/) and [Adobe's Brackets editor](https://twitter.com/brackets/status/400678387045642241)

project.name: CSS Colors
project.description: A tool that helps you convert between the different CSS-accepted color formats (including name keywords) as well as share them with others.

project.name: CSS3 patterns gallery
project.description: An interactive gallery that demonstrated what's possible with just CSS gradients. It also allows you to edit the code, to experiment with gradients yourself.
project.impact: It has been [featured in a number of books](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22css3patterns%22&tbm=bks), talks, workshops. It was used by Opera Software to fine-tune their CSS gradients implementation.
project.innovation: The gallery and the corresponding blog posts started the — now widespread — practice of using hard stops in CSS gradients to easily create background patterns and other graphics.

project.name: Chainvas
project.description: Chainvas is a tiny generic chaining library that can make any API's methods chainable (like jQuery). Official plugins for the DOM and the Canvas API included.
project.innovation: Uses reflection to read what methods are available and wrap them, making it generic enough that it can work with any API, no need to know anything about it in advance.

project.name: CSS gradients please!
project.description: A tool that converts the standard gradient syntax to -webkit-gradient and adds the rest of the prefixes

project.name: CSS3 structural pseudo-class selector tester
project.description: A tool that helps you learn how the :nth-whatever() CSS3 pseudo-classes work.

project.name: HTML5 <progress> polyfill
project.description: A very thorough polyfill for the HTML5 `<progress>` element.

project.name: StronglyTyped
project.description: A library for constants and strongly typed variables in JavaScript.

project.name: Incrementable
project.description: A script that enables incrementing/decrementing multiple numeric values in textfields with the keyboard arrow keys.

project.name: Inspire.js
project.description: My slide deck framework, built exclusively with open web technologies. Includes plugins for editable CSS regions, syntax hightlighting and more. Originally released under the name CSSS in 2010, rewritten in 2018 and renamed to Inspire.js

project.name: rgba.php
project.description: A server-side script that automatically generates semi-transparent PNGs to be used as fallbacks for RGBA colors.
